body.title: Arka Fincap Redefining Finance Through Technology
body.description: In this conversation, Suman Saurav, CTO of Arka Fincap, shares insights into how the company has leveraged advanced tools and ...
body.article_content:
Arka Fincap has embraced technology to streamline its operations and enhance customer experiences. By utilizing tools such as low-code platforms, automation, and cloud infrastructure, the company has significantly reduced processing times and operational costs. This approach has enabled efficient loan processing, seamless fintech integrations, and data-driven decision-making. Arka’s journey highlights the role of technology in modernizing financial services while balancing scalability, compliance, and customer-centricity.

Advertisment

Collaborating with fintech partners through standardized APIs has been pivotal in enhancing our loan sourcing capabilities and meeting customer expectations for speed and efficiency.

In this conversation, Suman Saurav, CTO of Arka Fincap, shares insights into how the company has leveraged advanced tools and platforms to automate operations, enhance customer engagement, and maintain cost efficiency. From utilizing low-code platforms for rapid deployment to building a cloud-first infrastructure, Saurav delves into the technologies shaping Arka’s journey and the lessons learned along the way. Excerpts from the interview:

How has Arka Fincap leveraged technology to streamline its operations and enhance customer experience? What specific technologies or tools have been instrumental in this transformation?

Advertisment

Arka Fincap has pioneered a technology-driven operational model aimed at optimizing efficiency and enhancing customer satisfaction. From inception, the company committed to a robust infrastructure built on contemporary technology, allowing automation of critical processes such as customer onboarding, loan sanctioning, and disbursement. These advancements have drastically reduced processing times and operational costs.

Key technologies include:

• Low-Code/ No-Code Platforms: These have accelerated the development of the Loan Origination System, enabling rapid product launches and program adjustments without heavy reliance on the IT systems. This adaptability ensures a swift response to market dynamics.

Advertisment

• Standardized APIs: Seamless integration with fintech partners has been achieved through APIs, enabling efficient data exchange and streamlined workflows.

• Automation: Processes like loan decision-making and disbursements are now automated, achieving turnaround times as low as four seconds. This efficiency boosts transaction volumes without increasing overhead.

• Advanced Analytics: Tools such as Inferyx and Power BI provide insights into customer behaviour and business performance, supporting strategic decision-making.

Advertisment

Can you elaborate on Arka’s approach to cost optimization in the context of digital transformation? How have you managed to balance the need for advanced technology to maintain a frugal cost structure?

Arka Fincap has embraced a cost-conscious strategy that integrates advanced technology while maintaining a lean cost structure:

• Cloud-Based Infrastructure: Utilizing a pay-as-you-go model, the cloud infrastructure scales resources based on demand, minimizing costs associated with physical hardware.

Advertisment

• Low-Code/No-Code Platforms: The implementation of low-code / no-code platforms for Loan Origination System has been instrumental in reducing development costs and time. This has empowered business analysts to make changes to applications without needing extensive IT intervention, allowing for rapid deployment of new features or adjustments to existing processes. This agility not only cuts down on development costs but also accelerates the time-to-market for new products.

Arka Fincap’s digital transformation is built on a foundation of empathy, agility, and technology, ensuring that we stay customer-focused while driving sustainable business growth.

• Unified Loan Management System: A single LMS consolidates data management, reducing technology investment and simplifying reconciliation processes.

Advertisment

• SaaS Applications: Functions like HR management and expense tracking leverage SaaS solutions, offering flexibility and cost efficiency.

What role have SaaS and cloud computing played in Arka’s digital transformation journey? How have these technologies enabled you to achieve infinite scalability while managing costs effectively?

Advertisment

SaaS and cloud computing are central to Arka Fincap’s digital transformation:

• Cloud Infrastructure: Enables scalable, cost-effective operations with a pay-as-you-go model that adjusts resources based on demand.

• Infinite Scalability: The flexibility of cloud solutions accommodates fluctuating demands without the need for additional hardware.

• SaaS Applications: These streamline operations, reduce overhead, and provide access to the latest tools, ensuring operational agility.

Can you share specific examples of how Arka has quantified the benefits of its technology investments in terms of cost savings, efficiency gains, and improved customer satisfaction?

Arka Fincap’s technology investments have delivered measurable outcomes:

• Cost Savings: Automation of loan processes reduces operational expenses and staffing requirements, achieving turnaround times of four seconds.

• Customer Satisfaction: Arka’s product offering like the Uday loan service for small ticket loans against property offers tailored solutions for MSMEs, addressing unmet needs and fostering trust.

• Data-Driven Decisions: Advanced analytics tools enable informed decision-making, improving resource allocation and service delivery.

• Employee Support: Our in-house chatbot Vidya enhances internal efficiencies by centralizing access to policy information.

How does Arka ensure compliance with evolving regulations in the financial services sector while embracing digital transformation?

Arka Fincap has adopted a proactive approach to ensure compliance with evolving regulations in the financial services sector while embracing digital transformation.

Data security is critical in the lending sector, and Arka addresses this by adhering strictly to regulatory guidelines and implementing best practices in cybersecurity.

Here’s an overview of how the company manages this balance:

• Integration of Technology and Operations: Arka Fincap has established a unique model that intertwines technology with operations, allowing for streamlined processes that enhance compliance. The integration of digital tools enables the company to automate regulatory reporting and compliance workflows, reducing the risk of human error and ensuring timely adherence to regulatory changes.

• Continuous Monitoring of Regulatory Changes: The compliance team at Arka is dedicated to closely monitoring regulatory developments within the Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) sector. As regulations evolve, such as the adoption of Indian Accounting Standards (IND AS) and Scale-Based Regulations (SBR), Arka ensures that these guidelines are thoroughly evaluated and swiftly integrated into their operations. This agility allows them to remain compliant without significant disruptions to their business processes.

• Data Security and Compliance Frameworks: Data security is critical in the lending sector, and Arka addresses this by adhering strictly to regulatory guidelines and implementing best practices in cybersecurity. The company has instituted measures for protecting customer data, including employee identity management and data obfuscation where necessary. These practices not only safeguard sensitive information but also ensure compliance with data protection regulations.

• Risk Management Tools: Arka employs robust risk management frameworks that include tools such as Expected Credit Loss (ECL), Early Warning Signals (EWS) mechanisms and Power BI analytics. These tools facilitate continuous monitoring of various risks, from asset quality to governance and liquidity, enabling the company to address potential compliance issues proactively. By utilizing data-driven insights, Arka can make informed decisions that align with regulatory requirements.

Are there any strategic partnerships or collaborations that Arka has formed to accelerate its digital transformation journey?

Arka Fincap has strategically partnered with various organizations to accelerate its digital transformation journey, particularly focusing on enhancing its offerings in the MSME lending sector. Here are some key partnerships and collaborations that have played a significant role in this transformation:

• Co-Lending Partnership: Arka Fincap has established a co-lending arrangement with banks and NBFCs aimed at providing loans to Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs).

• Fintech Collaborations: Arka has formed partnerships with multiple fintech companies to enhance its loan sourcing capabilities. These collaborations enable seamless integration by utilizing standardized APIs. The integration also allows for quicker loan processing times and improved service delivery, aligning with customer expectations for fast and efficient financial services.

• Adoption of SaaS Solutions: Arka leverages various SaaS (Software as a Service) applications to streamline operations across different functions such as HR management, expense tracking, and customer relationship management. This approach has resulted in cost efficiency and operational agility.

What is Arka’s long-term vision and goals for digital transformation?

Arka Fincap has articulated a clear long-term vision and set of goals for its digital transformation journey, focusing on leveraging technology to enhance operational efficiency, customer experience, and overall business growth.

• Empowering Financial Growth: Arka aims to drive financial empowerment by providing innovative and technology-enabled financial solutions. The company envisions itself as a robust, diversified institution that can facilitate growth for its clients in the MSME sector while ensuring sustainable value creation.

• Customer-Centric Approach: The organization is committed to enhancing customer experiences through empathy and agility. By focusing on creating differentiated customer journeys, Arka seeks to meet and exceed customer expectations in the financial services sector.

• Technology as a Key Enabler: Arka considers technology as a critical driver for business growth. Our long-term vision includes building a comprehensive IT architecture that supports seamless access to business systems and applications, thereby improving operational efficiency and service delivery.

Suman Saurav

CTO, Arka Fincap

aanchalg@cybermedia.co.in

body.title: Michael Sheen got a right roasting
body.description: Michael Sheen was left red-faced after taking a roasting from Michael McIntyre. The Good Omens actor appeared on the comedian ...
body.article_content:
Michael Sheen was left red-faced after taking a roasting from Michael McIntyre.

The Good Omens actor appeared on the comedian’s Big Show episode last night (25 January) where he was subjected to the infamous ‘Send to All’ challenge.

And this led to McIntyre calling out a ‘self-centred' discovery on Sheen’s phone.

Advert

As you’ll probably know, this is a pretty staple feature of the BBC show, when the comic gets a hold of a celebrity guest’s device and sends out a cringey message to all of their contacts live on stage.

Oh, and obviously has a bit of a scour through the contents of their phone first - how could he not?

Michael McIntyre found it hilarious (BBC)

So it was pretty understandable when Sheen admitted to having some nerves beforehand as he said: “It all seemed like a very good idea when I was first asked. Now it seems like a very bad idea.”

Advert

The Welshman watched on from the VIP box in the theatre with partner Anna Lundberg and her mum, Ingrid, as McIntyre took the plunge into his apps.

Both the live audience and viewers watched as the host uncovered Sheen’s most recent search on IMDb.

And turns out, it was himself. The Quiz actor explained: “Listen, sometimes...

“Sometimes, I have to look myself up, alright? Because I forget what I've been in.”

Advert

Honestly, fair enough - I can’t even remember what I had for tea last night.

His second most recent search was 'Gavin and Stacey' in a bit of a nod to the actor’s Welsh pride.

Then, McIntyre turned his attention to Sheen’s notes app while asking: “Is notes a bit personal?” As the star advised him to avoid.

But obviously, this was ignored and the comedian dove straight in as he found an entire page dedicated to the actor’s work history.

Advert

Michael Sheen was roasted (BBC)

This turned out to be the write-up of a bio for one of his projects and of course, McIntyre found it absolutely hilariously as he joked Sheen was 'self-centred'.

Having read that out aloud, the presenter carried on with the embarrassment as he turned his attention to the photos app.

Here he found plenty of selfies of the 55-year-old, including ones of him in disguise. And there was even a snap of his decapitated head from the infamous The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 scene.

Advert

McIntyre couldn’t help but point out that pretty much all the photos were of Sheen himself as he continued to comically roast him for being a bit self-obsessed.

body.title: SIGNS: Tennessee Republican U.S. Rep. Tim Burchett Believes Aliens Have Underwater Bases
body.description: Believe it or not, this isn't the first time that Rep. Tim Burchett has brought up his theory about underwater alien activity ...
body.article_content:
Click to share on Pocket (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Tumblr (Opens in new window)

Click to share on LinkedIn (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Reddit (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Telegram (Opens in new window)

Click to share on WhatsApp (Opens in new window)

Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)

Believe it or not, this isn’t the first time that Rep. Tim Burchett has brought up his theory about underwater alien activity.

Tennessee Representative Tim Burchett has taken the trending extraterrestrial conversation to the depths of Earth’s oceans.

According to a report from WREG Memphis News Channel 3 (via The Hill), The Republican congressman has openly declared his belief that aliens might be operating secret underwater bases right here on our planet. Burchett’s claims are now making waves in Washington and beyond due to the interesting intersection between religion and science that his beliefs clash on.

During a recent appearance on former Rep. Matt Gaetz’s One America News show, he clearly states that he arrived at this point base on his thought process of the unlimited power of the most high. “I just think travelin’ light years, I think it happens,” Burchett said. Burchett also pondered the unimaginable distances aliens might travel to reach Earth.

“The light from those stars that we see at night left there before the time of Christ,” he added, mixing astronomy and theology in his explanation.

Burchett’s fascination with the unknown isn’t new. Last year in April, following a classified briefing on Unidentified Anomalous Phenomena (UAP), he hinted that the U.S. government is deliberately withholding information about these mysterious occurrences.

“I think there’s a cover-up,” Burchett alleged. “We’ve had departments tell us that they have recovery units, but they won’t release full reports. Everything’s covered up.”

The congressman’s interest in aliens gained momentum in the summer of 2023, when whistleblowers came forward during a series of UAP hearings. These insiders alleged that the government has long concealed evidence of advanced crafts of either foreign or extraterrestrial origin.

Burchett took action by requesting the intelligence community’s inspector general investigate these shocking claims. Burchett described one case that had him particularly spooked. “When they tell me something’s moving at hundreds of miles an hour underwater, and our capabilities…and these things, this one was, it was large as a football field underwater,” he said. “And this was a documented case, and…and I have an admiral telling me this stuff.” he said.

Burchett has even led efforts to establish a UAP caucus in the House, joining a bipartisan group of lawmakers demanding greater transparency from the military on all things alien. With tens of millions spent on mysterious investigations, Burchett believes Americans deserve the full story—even if it means unearthing secrets that sound straight out of a sci-fi movie.

Interestingly, Burchett isn’t the first U.S. lawmaker to explore the outer edges of plausibility. One prominent example of recent congressional conspiracy theories involves Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.). In 2018, she speculated about a secretive “space laser” potentially being used to start wildfires in California.

The theory, which linked wildfires to a powerful and shadowy elite, was widely debunked and criticized but highlighted her willingness to amplify far-fetched claims. Her comments about various conspiracy theories, including QAnon, have sparked national debates and raised concerns about the influence of such ideas within government institutions.

body.title: Ronny LeBlanc presents local UFO history
body.description: Learn about the history of UFO sightings in Massachusetts as well as Bigfoot encounters that continue to this day in and ...
body.article_content:
LANCASTER — Learn about the history of UFO sightings in Massachusetts as well as Bigfoot encounters that continue to this day in and around Leominster State Forest, as Ronny LeBlanc presents “Paranormal Hot Spots” at 11 a.m., Saturday, Feb. 1, at Thayer Memorial Library, 717 Main St.

“I will be highlighting locations around the country that have witnessed UFOs, strange lights, Bigfoot and other Cryptids for hundreds of years and explore why this is the case,” said LeBlanc. “I will then dive into three locations right here in New England where you just might be able to have a sighting or an experience yourself.”

LeBlanc is an independent researcher, screenwriter, and author of two critically acclaimed and best-selling books “Monsterland: Encounters with UFOs, Bigfoot and Orange Orbs” and the follow up book, titled “Monsterland: Shamans, Sasquatch, Synchronicity and High Strangeness”, which detail the history and connection between the various phenomena, highlighting his experience and a research area called Monsterland in central Massachusetts.

He currently has 51 talks scheduled around the country and is excited to announce several upcoming projects dealing with UFOs, as well as a Cannes Film Festival entry which is a Bigfoot documentary filmed in England, and the launching of Blue Tiger, an AI-fueled marketing agency based out of Worcester.

“I absolutely love doing these library presentations, specifically because they [libraries] were the source of inspiration and wonder for me,” LeBlanc said. “The library is where I learned about these subjects that are the greatest mysteries of our time.”

LeBlanc believes that by giving back and providing these free talks for the public, he will motivate curiosity-inspired people to read physical books again, go to libraries, and engage with others in their community who are experiencing similar encounters or sightings.

“When they suddenly realize that they’re not alone and that others just like them – who live next to them as neighbors or coworkers — are seeing something that many others never have a chance to experience — that is the greatest gift for me,” he said.

To register for this presentation, visit Thayer Memorial Library’s website at thayermemoriallibrary.org or call 978-368-8928. For more information on Ronny LeBlanc, his books and shows, you are welcome to visit his website at ronnyleblanc.com.

body.description: For the first time, scientists have measured the shape of an electron in solids, opening the door to advances in quantum ...
body.article_content:
For the first time, researchers have measured the shape of an electron as it moves through a solid. This achievement could open a new way of looking at how electrons behave inside different materials.

Their discovery highlights many effects that could be relevant to everything from quantum information science to electronics manufacturing.

Those findings come from a team led by physicist Riccardo Comin, MIT’s Class of 1947 Career Development Associate Professor of Physics and leader of the work, in collaboration with other institutions.

“We’ve essentially developed a blueprint for obtaining some completely new information that couldn’t be obtained before,” says Comin. His colleague and co-author, Mingu Kang, performed much of this research at MIT before continuing at Cornell University.

New angles on electron shape

Physicists have examined electrons for decades, but the wave-like aspect of these particles brings extra complexity. Electrons can be described not just as small points, but also as “wave functions.”

These wave functions look like shapes or surfaces in higher-dimensional spaces. Sometimes these shapes are relatively simple. Other times, they’re tangled and tricky to measure.

By using angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy, or ARPES, the team recorded details about how electrons behaved as light hit them.

ARPES helped them pin down a previously elusive property of electrons that holds the key to better understanding their geometry.

Why electron shape matters

In usual settings, we talk about an electron’s energy or velocity. Those are familiar concepts. Geometry, on the other hand, points to the patterns or forms that electron waves can take when arranged in a solid.

Quantum geometry affects how these particles interact, pair up, and even give rise to unusual behaviors. One example is superconductivity, where electrons zip along a material without resistance.

Another is when electrons form orderly patterns, a bit like a collection of synchronized dancers. Observing geometry could help scientists design new materials with novel electronic traits.

The kagome connection

The team measured this geometric effect in a class of materials called kagome metals. Kagome metals are named for a repeating pattern of atoms that resembles a series of interlocking triangles. This lattice structure can influence how electrons navigate and share energy.

Physicists have long found kagome metals interesting because they host special behaviors that aren’t common in many other materials.

Observing the geometry inside them could explain why electrons in these metals sometimes align in peculiar ways that set off advanced superconductivity or other strange effects.

ARPES and quantum shapes

During ARPES experiments, researchers shine a beam of photons on a crystal. The light pushes electrons out of the material, allowing scientists to measure those electrons’ angles and spins.

By gathering that data, they reconstruct how electrons inside the crystal are moving and what shapes they form.

This method is demanding because it requires intricate equipment and specialized facilities. Yet it gives a unique window into what happens on distances smaller than a billionth of an inch.

Applications and potential benefits

A precise measurement of quantum geometry can lead to progress in areas that rely on electron control. Quantum computing, for instance, depends on maintaining stable electronic states while performing computations.

Researchers want materials that can reliably keep these states without unwanted disruptions. If scientists understand and possibly design the geometry of electrons, they might improve superconductors or even develop electronic devices that lose very little energy through heat.

With energy efficiency becoming ever more critical, there’s real value in controlling electron flow on such tiny scales.

Insights from global teamwork

This study was a partnership among institutions spanning different parts of the world. Collaborators brought together theoretical and experimental backgrounds.

Their collective expertise made it possible to design, synthesize, and measure the electronic structure of a kagome metal.

The pandemic forced some members to work remotely, but it also enabled other team members to take on new roles in labs that were partially shut down.

That unexpected shift helped push the work forward and demonstrated how closely linked theory and experiment must be when tackling high-precision measurements.

One electron shape, many possibilities

Quantum geometry is far richer than standard geometry we learn in everyday math. The shape of an electron’s wave function isn’t like a typical circle or a neat sphere. It can take on forms that twist and loop in higher dimensions.

Observing that shape in a real material confirms predictions that theorists have pursued for a long time. It means those theoretical constructs describing wave functions have real, measurable consequences.

And now, there is a proven route to measure them, so future studies might target exotic materials that exhibit other patterns or new behaviors.

What happens next?

Scientists plan to refine techniques like ARPES and adapt them to explore a range of materials. They hope to see how quantum geometry influences conductivity, magnetism, and other conditions that matter for practical applications.

Physicists also see promise in discovering how manipulating geometry might encourage electrons to swap their usual habits for more synchronized, cooperative behavior.

That synchronization is important for technologies that rely on controlling multiple electrons at once, such as quantum sensors or memory elements.

Experts say these findings will likely inspire more ambitious experiments to uncover aspects of quantum geometry we haven’t been able to measure before.

With each new result, materials researchers step closer to engineering designs for the electronic components of tomorrow. The electron might be tiny, but it’s revealing secrets about shaping the future of technology.

The study is published in Nature Physics.

—–

body.title: Quantum Computing Benefits for Advanced Optimization Problems
body.description: Have you ever wondered how certain problems are so complex that even the fastest computers struggle to solve them? These ...
body.article_content:
Have you ever wondered how certain problems are so complex that even the fastest computers struggle to solve them? These types of problems are often found in industries like transportation, finance, healthcare, and science. They’re called “optimization problems,” where the goal is to find the best solution out of many possible options.

While regular computers (called “classical computers“) are great for many tasks, they can have a hard time handling these massive challenges. Enter quantum computers.

Quantum computers are an exciting new kind of technology that could change the way we solve difficult problems, especially Quantum Computing Problems. Instead of using regular computer bits (which are like tiny on/off switches), quantum computers use something called “quantum bits,” or qubits.

Qubits are super special because they follow the rules of quantum physics, which means they can process information in ways that classical computers can’t. This makes quantum computers much more powerful at solving certain types of puzzles.

What Are Optimization Problems?

Optimization problems sound fancy, but you deal with them every day without even realizing it. Imagine you’re trying to pick the fastest route to school on a map, or you’re deciding how to spend your pocket money to get the best value. These are simple examples of optimization problems—finding the best option out of many choices.

Now imagine you work at an airport and have to decide the best way to schedule hundreds of flights, manage thousands of bags, and make everything run smoothly without delays. Or maybe you work for a delivery company and you want to find the most efficient way to deliver millions of packages across the country. These problems are way too complicated to solve with just guesswork!

Regular computers try to solve these tough problems by testing every possible solution one by one, which can take an enormous amount of time. Even supercomputers may need days, months, or even years to do the job, depending on how big the problem is.

What Makes Quantum Computers Different?

Quantum computers are special because they use principles from quantum mechanics, a branch of science that studies the tiniest building blocks of our universe—like atoms and particles. Unlike classical computers, which use bits that can be either 0 or 1, qubits can be in multiple states at once, thanks to something called “superposition.” This allows quantum computers to look at many possible solutions simultaneously, instead of one by one.

Quantum computers also use something called “entanglement,” where qubits are connected in a way that lets them share information instantly. These features allow quantum computers to perform certain calculations much faster than classical computers.

For optimization problems, this means quantum computers can solve puzzles with millions (or even billions!) of possibilities in a fraction of the time it would take a classical computer.

This breakthrough is particularly exciting for industries like logistics, where the rise of technology has revolutionized traditional operations. If you interested in exploring this further, can check out our blog, “F2000s and the Rise of Technology in Logistics,” to learn how advanced computing and innovation are shaping supply chains globally.

Real-Life Benefits of Quantum Computing in Optimization

Now that we understand how quantum computers work, let’s explore some real-life benefits for solving optimization problems.

1. Faster Deliveries and Better Logistics

Have you ever ordered something online and tracked its delivery route? Companies like Amazon or FedEx need to figure out the fastest and cheapest way to deliver packages to millions of customers. Using quantum computers, these companies could create better delivery plans in real time, saving money and ensuring you get your package as quickly as possible.

2. Smarter Traffic Management

Traffic jams are another optimization challenge. Cities around the world face growing traffic problems as more and more cars hit the roads. Quantum computing can help plan better traffic flows, reduce congestion, and make public transportation more efficient. This could save time, lower fuel usage, and reduce pollution!

3. Improved Healthcare Scheduling

Hospitals deal with optimization problems all the time, like scheduling surgeries, assigning doctors, and managing beds for patients. Quantum computers could help hospitals make better schedules that improve patient care and reduce waiting times. This means more lives saved and a smoother healthcare experience.

4. More Accurate Financial Predictions

Banks and investment companies often deal with risky decisions, like where to invest money or how to predict market changes. These are complex optimization problems that involve analyzing a huge amount of data. Quantum computers could help make faster and smarter financial decisions, which could stabilize markets and improve the global economy.

5. Advancing Science and Research

From designing new medicines to improving renewable energy systems, scientists rely on optimization to solve tough problems. Quantum computers can speed up this research and bring us closer to breakthroughs in important areas like curing diseases or fighting climate change.

Challenges and the Future of Quantum Computing

Quantum computers sound amazing, but they’re not perfect yet. Building and maintaining them is incredibly hard. They need to be kept in extremely cold environments and are still in the early stages of development. Right now, only a few companies and research labs have working quantum computers.

Still, progress is happening quickly. Scientists and engineers are working hard to make quantum computers more powerful and accessible. Many believe that within the next 10 to 20 years, we’ll see quantum computing become a common tool for solving real-world problems.

Why Should You Care About Quantum Computing?

Even if you’re not a scientist or an engineer, quantum computing is something exciting to keep an eye on. The benefits it could bring, from better technologies to smarter ways of solving problems, have the potential to impact nearly every part of our lives. Quantum computing could lead to a better, more efficient, and more sustainable future.

Think of quantum computers like the superheroes of the technology world. They take on the toughest challenges and uncover solutions that normal computers just can’t handle. And who knows? Maybe one day you’ll be working on quantum computing or benefiting from its amazing advancements!

Quantum computing may still sound like science fiction to some, but it’s quickly becoming a reality. Its ability to solve advanced optimization problems could transform industries and improve the world in countless ways.

The possibilities are limitless, and we’re just getting started! Explore theerone for more insights.

body.title: Teenage girls arrested over Instagram video showing them dancing in front of Iranian war memorial – and could face jail
body.description: TWO teenage girls have been arrested by Iran’s chilling morality police for dancing together in public. Tehran’s twisted laws ...
body.article_content:
TWO teenage girls have been arrested by Iran's chilling morality police for dancing together in public.

Tehran's twisted laws mean the duo could now face prison time after draconian officials branded their outfits "inappropriate" despite them wearing jeans and jumpers.

5 Two teenage girls have been arrested by Iran's chilling morality police for dancing together in public Credit: X/FSeifikaran

5 The pair performed a choreographed dance in front of the Monument to the Unknown Martyrs of the Sacred Defence war memorial in Tehran Credit: X/FSeifikaran

5 Dancing is banned in Iran with the girls also accused of wearing 'inappropriate outfits', according to local media Credit: X/FSeifikaran

Viral footage released by the girls and posted onto Instagram soon caught the evil eyes of the Iranian authorities.

In the video, the pair perform a choreographed dance routine together in front of the Monument to the Unknown Martyrs of the Sacred Defence war memorial in Tehran.

The monument, designed by Italian architect Marcello D'Olivo, was built to honour those killed in the Iran-Iraq War between 1980 and 1982.

The morality police are said to have detained the women shortly after the video was uploaded.

Dancing in groups has been strictly banned in Iran since the 1979 Islamic Revolution with officials labelling it a "sinful act".

Iranian authorities also said the girl's outfits were "inappropriate", according to Iran International.

The footage shows the women both wearing jeans with one of them having rips in hers but no skin on show.

The same woman is also in a blue cropped top which is covered up by a hooded jacket.

A pink bandage is wrapped around her right hand.

Her friend has a multicoloured sweater on.

Iran's violence against women continues under repressive regime

Both also have their hair uncovered despite the morality police typically forcing all women to conceal their hair.

A growing number of young girls have turned a blind eye to these strict policies across the past few years.

The ladies are also believed to have had their Instagram accounts blocked after they were detained for posting the dance.

The official punishment the women face is still unconfirmed with Iran's authorities known to uphold unjust charges against those who go against the regime.

According Article 637 of the Iranian Penal Code, dancing in public is classed as a "crime against public modesty".

People in similar positions as the women have been sentenced to flogging by 99 lashes in the past.

In 2014, six young men and women were handed down suspended sentences of a year behind bars as well as 91 lashes for a dance video.

They were arrested after being caught in a video dancing to Pharrell Williams' hit song "Happy".

TEHRAN'S HORROR REGIME

Women are facing tighter restrictions than ever before in Iran with a new bill is set to toughen up regulations governing how they can dress and act in public.

The bill says that anyone found “naked, semi-naked, or wearing clothing deemed improper in public” can be arrested without question and handed over to the judicial authorities.

People refusing to comply could be banned from leaving Iran or even placed on a social media hiatus of up to two years if they post content deemed inappropriate online.

The law is yet to be passed by Tehran's government but officers are already implementing it, claim several women.

The footage of the woman in the airport appears to be the latest example of Iranian women growing tired of the mandatory hijab laws.

Back in November, a courageous Iranian student stripped to her underwear after she was allegedly assaulted by morality cops over her hijab.

Iran's Morality Police UNDER Iranian law, rooted in Sharia law, women must cover their hair with a hijab and wear long, loose-fitting clothing. The Guidance Patrol - aka the morality police - are in charge of arresting women who violate the conservative dress code. Tasked with ensuring Islamic morals are respected, they spend their days patrolling public spaces in vans to crack down on "improper" behaviour and clothing. Women detained by cops are either given a warning or bundled into a van and whisked away to a "correctional facility" or a police station. They are then lectured on how to dress before being released to their male relatives. Since the 1980s, many women have been beaten to death by the callous morality police, or tortured into given false confessions. Various clips this year have shown their increased presence as the country ramps up its violent crackdowns on women. One disturbing video shows the moment Iran's twisted morality police hurl a woman in the back of one of their patrol vans. Before this a woman was filmed tackling a girl to the ground and attacking her as she screamed - seemingly because she hadn't covered her hair. Video has shown the morality police snatching women off the streets and bundling them into vans for wearing jeans in public. Tehran announced a fresh crackdown on "anomalies" to its religious rules under the "Nour Project" in April. The Jerusalem Post reports suggest crackdowns on behaviour have been violent. Sexual harassment, beatings, arrests and the use of tasers have been reported around the country.

Her clothes and headscarf were both torn during the alleged assault at the Azad University of Science and Research in Tehran, Iran International reports.

Footage shows the woman sat near-nude outside a university before being bundled violently into a car by police.

She was also reportedly accused of being mentally ill and taken to a nearby hospital.

This "headscarf revolution" was all fuelled by the death of Mahsa Amini in 2022.

Amini died in the custody of Tehran's "morality police" after being arrested for violating Iran's hijab rules.

She was beaten to death for wearing an "improper" hijab on September 16.

Women of all ages ripped off their compulsory hijabs at public demonstrations in defiance of the nation’s feared morality police.

Hundreds of people were killed, including dozens of security personnel, in a brutal crackdown and thousands of protesters were arrested.

Reports of torture and death at the hands of officials have also surfaced.

5 The girls had their hair uncovered and some skin on show during the dance despite wearing jeans and jumpers Credit: X/FSeifikaran
